nodes.bodyText:
Before this fix the artifact report for grpc-google-common-protos was showing Upper Bound Fixes for jsr305 version 3.0.1. But that version should not appear in the tree because grpc-core declares exclusions.
Tree: https://screenshot.googleplex.com/g8cQ3BXq36O.png
The comment above was correct but grpc-google-common-protos:1.14.0's dependency tree still has old protobuf-java dependency. So the section should be red.

This is the main purpose of this fix. The levelOrder does not need to call resolveCompileTimeDependencies.
This implementation was not preserving exclusions element.
Before this PR, this test would fail because levelOrder was not respecting exclusion elements.
The nodes in the tree changed because now exclusion elements take effect entire subtree.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -74,8 +74,6 @@ public void testFindUpdates() throws RepositoryException {
                 + "upgrade com.google.protobuf:protobuf-java:3.5.1 to 3.6.0",
             "com.google.api.grpc:proto-google-iam-v1:0.12.0 needs to "
                 + "upgrade com.google.protobuf:protobuf-java:3.5.1 to 3.6.0",
-            "com.google.guava:guava-jdk5:17.0 needs to "
-                + "upgrade com.google.code.findbugs:jsr305:1.3.9 to 3.0.2",

nodes.bodyText: No need to wrap DependencyGraph with DependencyGraphResult. Because this function does not encounter UnresolvedArtifactProblem any more.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -316,15 +313,11 @@ public static UnresolvableArtifactProblem createUnresolvableArtifactProblem(
    * just follows the given dependency tree starting with firstNode.
    *
    * @param firstNode node to start traversal
-   * @param graphTraversalOption option to recursively resolve the dependency to build complete
-   *     dependency tree, with or without dependencies of provided scope
    */
-  private DependencyGraphResult levelOrder(
-      DependencyNode firstNode, GraphTraversalOption graphTraversalOption) {
+  private DependencyGraph levelOrder(DependencyNode firstNode) {

nodes.bodyText: Without this class, this test would throw StackOverflowError.
There's only one parent. Perhaps this is ancestors? e.g. like in XPath
Nice. Updated to ancestor.

Is node the child to remove? If so, rename to child.
Also it could be a tad clearer if the argument order match the method name. That is,
removeChildFromParent( DependencyNode child, DependencyNode parent)
Updated.
I think this method can be static
Updated to static.
Set feels wrong for parents, because these are ordered, even if we're not using the order here.

Set is preferred here. Using a Set for ancestors gives O(1) lookup. At line 47:
if (ancestors.contains(artifact)) {
static
Updated
How many elements are we talking about though? 10? Maybe 20 at the outside? Even if it were 1000 the difference is unlikely to be measurable.

Sometimes around 1,000,000 nodes in a full dependency tree.
#1145 (comment)

The tree height (ancestors.size) is not big, but this ancestors.contains is called that many times.
I'll measure the speed difference when I have time; 20 equals calls may be faster than 1 hashCode plus equals call.
